review.review_text: Thanks to this app, I no longer have to make my own reviews manually and cover the answer with my hand. I haven't failed a single exam, not that it's common or anything, but thanks to this I have no worries. I have given my account to my fellow friends from class, thanks to the syncing option, and we take turns making our reviews through this. I really wished I had found this app sooner it has really been a life changer and I love apps that do just that, change lives. Thanks a bunch for making this! :D

review.review_title: Great app, just make sure to export your collection before upgrading Android
review.review_text: On Android Nougat 7.1 it's has become impossible to sync your collection across devices rendering the cloud sync feature useless. This error appears when trying to login. Note: This error might happen when upgrading to Android 7, but a simple reinstallation should fix it so make sure to backup your collection beforehand. I've updated the review score to reflect this. A clean install SHOULDN'T encounter this issue so it's only relevant for previous users.

Not a big deal being a useful and free app, but I would recommend to anyone with the same issue just to save time if the sync keeps mumping up. Huge thanks to the Dev Team!

review.star_rating: Rated 3 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: Useful, but the Android and PC Desktop versions of this software are missing many of the useful editing features available to iPhone/Apple users. You can waste a lot of time watching tutorials, hoping that they will get around to mentioning the existence of Android or PC or showing the non-Apple/iPhone interfaces (spoiler: they don't). And you can waste a lot of time trying to find the missing features you saw in the tutorials, (spoiler: they are not there). Finally, you can search their manual and supporting documentation for some sort of acknowledgement that these features are missing form the Android/PC versions of the software, so you can allow yourself to stop searching in vain and go to bed, but this search will be fruitless too. So, if you want an intelligent program training you on flashcards using spaced repetition, and you don't mind that you can do only the most nominal of editing of the cards themselves, this one is for you. But don't expect greatness, or supporting materials for non Apple users.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: Terrific app! Thanks to all who work on it. Two small requests: 1. The language I'm learning uses three fairly obscure characters: 匹 骗 茍. These show up fine on the desktop version, but render as blank spaces or a ? on the app. These misrenders then get synced back onto the database. Is there a chance this could get fixed, or should I go ahead and find alternate characters to represent them? 2. One of the advantages of a mobile app flashcard system is that you can easily create audio flashcards in the field. The current app requires five touches to record audio (+, Add, paperclip, record audio, RECORD). It would be great to be able to do this in fewer steps, though I realize that might not be possible without overcrowding the interface.

review.star_rating: Rated 4 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: This is the excellent flash card so far that I have experienced. Previously I used Brainscape on iOS, but it lack of customization features comparing to Anky (and AnkiDroid). With this app, you are able to store and back up multimedia decks externally, and even share with others. That is above my expectations. I wish I know this app earlier. The second feature I like and use frequently is the playback, it makes much easy to review what have been learned. There is still room for improvements, for example, users can choose different algorithms/ways to select a card for studying/reviewing, randomly card selection is an option. The reason is that for big decks, too much repetition for some cards makes the learner tired and wastes time. That is a reason I dropped one star_rating.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: Orig 2/13/2016: Was a nice little application to practice words while waiting in line at the store. That was until all my decks just disappeared. Now, why would I want to use the application without anything to practice?! Update 2/14/2016 I thought that this was caused by a automatic update to a version that forced a logging into the site to use any features. Or at least all that was prompted for was to login to the site, and the decks showed zero. I had built a few decks. I feel that maybe for an Open Source project still alive, I judged to harshly after my initial shock. I'm still going to have to dig through old storage backups for any possible files. I already deleted the application on the phone. 5/3/2016 I was able to remove the /storage/sdcard0/AnkiDroid/ folder. Install the Application again. Next, I restored the last copy of the folder before the card sets disappeared. Then star_ratingted the application and the cards all showed-up again. I'm happy that I had the backup and that it was that simple.

review.star_rating: Rated 1 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: I am completely lost as to why this app gets so many good reviews, because for me, it is AWFUL - at least as far as custom decks are concerned. It is far too over-complicated. Bear witness. Even trying to explain why it is so terrible will be confusing, and then bear in mind, working with the app is even worse. For example, it totally tries to own when and what I can study. It disappears my cards if it thinks I have studied them enough, forcing me to go and figure out how to put them back into the study session based on how many days to advance my review session. If I want to set up a custom study session to force it to allow me to study what I want, when I want, again it disappears the original deck - where I can no longer browse my list of cards, which btw, I have to do whenever I want to see a custom field because the app does not make it easy to add the field to the study deck. If none of this makes sense, then you are in the same boat I am in 鈥? only hopefully you haven鈥檛 put time and effort into creating a custom deck with this (cr)app.

review.star_rating: Rated 4 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: Tried to import .anki files, didn't work, kind of dumb when your apps name is AnkiDroid, no? Only .akpg is allowed. The developer's review_texts made clear why it did not work, however backwards compatibility might be more helpful than a guide on how to convert the old format to the new one. review.star_rating: Rated 3 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: I like this app but there are a few things I wish I could change. I wish I could see all of my cards in a deck in a list so I could choose which to look at. I wish I could make decks on my computer and there were a way to synch them on my phone through an account. I wish the push notifications would send when cards are due, and not only when I actually open the app. What use is that? I wish the push notifications didn't resend any time my screen turns off in the middle of studying a deck. I wish there were some pre-made decks for students in popular subjects such as anatomy or psychology or languages. Maybe charge a dollar for access to pre made decks. It would really be worth it, because making flashcards for anatomy consumes way more time than I can afford, really, but I have to do it.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: I used this app once a few years ago and it was so buggy it was useless. Last year I star_ratingted using this app again and loved it. In fact, I didn't even realize it was the same app until I went to rate it and realized I had rated the old version. I use this app every single day. The whiteboard feature and desktop client set it above every other flash card app I have ever used. I love the drag and drop capability for images on the desktop version. Plus, the desktop version can be used on a USB drive, making it REALLY useful for editing flashcards on a public computer! I recommend this software to everyone who is looking for a good flashcard app. It beats quizzlet hands down. My only gripes are the fact that you can't re-hide the answers once you've 'flipped' the card (I scribble over the answer to get around this) and you can't make batch changes to cards (such as suspend, mark, or change card type)

In fact, in spite of doing this, it is now giving me cards from the wrong part of the deck. I wish there was some way you could fix the cards it's giving you if it somehow goes wrong like this.

review.star_rating: Rated 3 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: Is there still no option to reverse the cards? I really need this. Even if it were possible to duplicate a deck and then reverse the whole deck, that would be a good option.

review.star_rating: Rated 1 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: You'll spend as much time trying to set up this app and to work around all the bugs as you'll actually spend learning your target knowledge. It's highly customizable and all that, but it's almost as if the developer has made it as infuriatingly difficult as possible to set up and use. Something as simple as a 'Browse' button to change the import (sorry, the collection) path, for example, would make things so much easier. Instead, you need to type it all in, and it's even CASE SENSITIVE, for God's sake! It's like pre GUI nostalgia or something. There's no rhyme or reason to it. Audio files don't sync. The list of problems and flaws is endless. Potentially, a wonderful learning tool, but actually barely usable.

review.review_title: Top Notch SRS in your pocket
review.review_text: Disregard the review_text about not supporting audio and images, it does and more. This is Pro level software. The whole Anki system takes work to learn. Read the Anki manual to understand how to properly make and use decks/notes/cards/tags/filtered decks. There are loads of articles and forum posts about tweaks and best practices, I'd suggest reading the manual first. The software and system are a long term investment that if used properly will become a lifelong companion in memorization.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: Best Flashcard App on the market
review.review_text: There is no doubt that this app is the best flashcard app on the market. It is extremely flexible and offers countless ways to customize your deck. I personally prefer to create the cards on my desktop and sync with my portable devices. Include pictures and sound with your cards, enable the whiteboard to write your answers, require that the answer be typed in, create cloze cards etc. You can even create multiple cards with one click: forwards/backwards/spelling or use it to have one image with several labeled parts, each part with its own card. If you don't want all of this, you can also just keep your cards simple. I highly recommend watching a tutorial video or reading the manual so that you can make the most of this amazing app.

review.review_title: Fabulous once you get your head around it
review.review_text: As per review_title, this app is simply amazing. However, for the first-time user, it does look complicated until you understand the actual framework - i.e. how it was thought to work. A suggestion here - in the help system, change 'cards' for 'templates' where appropriate. Once i got my head around templates and different types, i got myself to design few common types i use most and bang! Adding actual flashcards now using the templates is as simple as it can be .... And i can use cloze-types, images, etc.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: Use it every day for everything
review.review_text: From the Kings of England to the poems of Yeats, JavaScript functions and Japanese kanji, I'm a walking dictionary thanks to Anki. It syncs to all devices, can be accessed through the browser or dedicated apps, and resets every day for a new session, focusing only on the cards that gave me trouble. I use it for presentations too: a card and a story for every PowerPoint slide. The front has the picture on the slide; the back has the point to be made. Using Anki prior to presenting makes nervousness vanish.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: Used for ages, and amazing - some ideas below
review.review_text: I've had this for ages. I originally hated it, but I later gave it a chance, and it has grown on me. I love it now. Feature #1: Can you make it so spacing affects position? The app ignores multiple spaces. Experimental feature #1: Can you make a feature to edit pieces of text in cards, like being able to make word(s) bold, different colours etc. (not all different shades though) I say experimental, so someone has the ability to turn it on/off, in case it makes it laggy. Experimental feature #2: Can you make it possible to input superscript and subscript numbers and signs (mainly for chemical equations - no android keyboards seem to have them) so like 1, 2, +, - (g) etc. Sorry that it's a massive wall of text. P.S. I can only use Ankidroid on my ASUS tablet, as I have no computer of my own. Experimental feature # 3: Can you integrate a drawing app? As in make it so I can draw in my notes and save it. A lot to ask, but these are mainly just things I would like. It's already definitely worth the 5 star_ratings.

review.star_rating: Rated 4 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: Helps in memorizing facts. please add progressive revelation of answer. For example, the first anatomy picture above had 3 facts on 3 separate lines. instead of just one 'Show Answer' button, have two buttons - 'Show next line' and 'Show all answer' or words to similar effect. This could be an option in settings for just having one button or the progressive two buttons. This would help in memorizing long answers - eg long verses, a longer lists than the above etc. I used lots of line breaks to make only the first line of the answer show. Scrolling line per line as I recite allows me to check for perfect recall per line before continuing. However with Anki updates, Anki now forces the display of most or all of the answer on hitting 'Show Answer'. All the cards have to be changed again to control the flow of answer being revealed. Too much at once and its difficult to check if I recited perfectly or not. It's just like an anatomy picture with 20 items. Answer 1, check, anwer 2 check -etc The hint would take lots of time to make each card. Show one line at a time would make cards easier to produce = more study time.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: It works! I've been using AnkiDroid for a psychopathology course in which I have to memorize huge amounts of diagnostic criteria, and it's helping a ton. I haven't run into any bugs, the synchronization is fast and easy so I can enter the flashcards on my laptop but also review them on my phone. I'd appreciate a more straightforward way to run it in cram mode (review everything, regardless of the memory-aiding algorithm), but it's a quick workaround on the user's end. Thanks for making a great, quality product with no ads!

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: In the 90s, hoping to study Sanskrit vocabulary more efficiently, I looked around for flexible, ergonomic, free flashcard software and finally resorted to writing my own. Today I am happy to report that AnkiDroid does exactly what I wanted. Adding cards is easy; the review interface is streamlined and practical to use with one thumb; and it does a good job of showing the cards I am struggling with. Synchronization between AnkiDroid (on a phone and a tablet), the desktop app, and the web site all works smoothly. The navigation in the AnkiDroid UI confused me somewhat when I first star_ratingting using it. For example, the back button moves up to a higher level in the app structure, rather than returning you to the previous screen, which is fine but unexpected. Once I got used to the layout it works well.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: Working good, finally. I am getting the occasional crash but a sensible backup strategy makes this easy to bear. I don't like the sync function though as it's very slow here in China, especially if you are trying to sync your entire media collection. I explored different ways to sync over USB, most of them causing AnkiDroid to crash for no apparent reason. At the time of this review Google have decided (very stupidly) to remove the USB Mass Storage file transfer protocol in favour of MTP, which is huge pile of odorous excrement. My plan was to use BeyondCompare (a folder comparison tool for Windows) to sync my Anki media. This is not possible with MTP, which forces you to use Anki's built-in sync function. Then I tried several USB Mass Storage enabling apps, some of which worked but AnkiDroid was crashing all the time. All the problems seemed to go away after I installed the latest version of BusyBox and and app called SG USB Mass Storage Enabler. Now I am able to manage my collection from my PC and I am very happy with the results. I hope Google consider re-adding USB Mass Storage mode though. MTP is retarded.

review.star_rating: Rated 1 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: I'm DONE with this program. For one, it doesn't allow cramming. When you finish a deck, you have FINISHED that deck for the day. I couldn't figure out how to reset it to let me study the words again. Which brings me to two, the program is unnecessary complicated. I used sticky kanji to study for the JLPT and while I couldn't make my own flashcards, I didn't need to read anything to star_ratingt using it. It just worked. Finally, the last straw. I go to make a deck for my final exam and it tells me my entries are in other decks. I can't have duplicates. It's okay, Anki, I want doubles, this is my compilation deck. No? YOU WON'T ALLOW ME? What kind of programmer make s program that won't let me use it? I am not going to search for and move my old cards. Oh and that option to try to keep pairs apart from one another? Doesn't work very well at all. I'm just really annoyed right now.

review.review_text: Anki is an very flexible tool that can be used to study many subjects in many ways. There is large ecosystem of community decks and plug-ins for the desktop version. The plug-ins can be useful across platforms. For example, I use the tts plug-in to generate audio clips for my Chinese vocab cards which are then available in the android app after a sync. Cards are highly customizable, they use html templates and can contain images and audio.

review.review_text: I used this to make cards for my language class and it worked really well. It not only allows you to make flashcards, but also manages your learning -- giving you daily assignments and organizing the cards you know well, the ones you know a bit, and the ones you don't know at all so that you get more repetition of things that are hard to acquire. I'm a teacher and find that this app uses the principles of learning very well. Synching with my computer is a little confusing though.

review.review_text: I really like this app, has a nice card creation interface for PC and droid. A lot of effort and thought went into this app nice to see! Card review is decent, but needs a mode more like real life index card reviews. Provide an option for rapidly flipping through cards instead of having to mark hard/easy, 1min,5min, etc to advance to next card. Also there's no backup unless we do manual copy/paste from the main deck summary page. If deck gets wiped, that's hours or days of lost work.

review.star_rating: Rated 2 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: One of the most annoying Apps I use
review.review_text: A flashcard app seems like it should be the type of thing so intuitive that students studying software development constantly build their own for their end of term projects. This type of software requires only a basic grasp of database usage and a simple user interface. So HOW IN THE HELL does ANKI make it SO F^$%# IMPOSSIBLE to do something as SIMPLE as REVERSE A DECK OF CARDS?!?!?! Flashcards 101: 99.9% of people who use apps like this will at some point need to study their cards forwards and backwards. There should be a 1-button click option to do so. Meanwhile, In ANKI-Land, Ive spent the last hour trying to follow through their ridiculously unnecessary steps to perform this simple task. Im still trying to figure it out as I write this.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: A little bit of a learning curve, but most definitely worth the effort!tTried AnkiDroid, found it too complicated, then tried the other free alternatives. The alternatives all had terrible interfaces and lacked a decent method on data entry via a computer (either via the web or a standalone desktop application) so I went back to AnkiDroid. It took me a little while to get used to the PC and Android apps, but once I did... Ohhh man the program really shines. The spaced repetition technique has really helped with my studies, and the interface is far more pleasant and clean than all the others. Definitely impressed with this free and fully featured flash cards app. Works perfectly on my Nexus 10 and Galaxy S2.

review.review_title: Can't export decks from the mobile app, very disappointed.
review.review_text: I *really* love the AnkiDroid app for its simple, easy-to-use interface and the SRS component. If you only plan on using it on your Android phone (and only need simple text cards), it's fantastic. However, I recently received an iPhone and wanted to transfer my decks. There is an iPhone version, but it costs $25 (understandably, it goes toward supporting development of all versions of the app); if you can't afford it at the moment (like me) there's always the simple mobile web version. But all of my decks were created on my Android and can't be exported. So I have to recreate my 100+ cards one at a time. ):

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: I learned 1,000 definitions in 10 days.. seriously
review.review_text: I'm in med school. The neuroscience block is a ~6 week period where students are pushed to the limit regarding memorization skills. Students are expected to learn well over 1,000 definitions over a 6 week period. I didn't truly realize this hefty requirement until roughly 10 days before the exam, as I was busy with practice questions and conceptual learning (usually the best way to study but NOT for the neuroscience block). I frantically searched for a worthy flashcard app. I had one I was happy with but it just couldn't handle the magnitude of flashcards I needed to make. Long story short, I learned over 1,000 definitions in 10 days with Anki... I should have failed... badly. I made a strong B instead. 1)Free on Google Play ($30 on iTunes) 2)Free desktop app with sync between devices and Mac/PC 3)More options/settings than I will ever need 4)Neuroscience Fact: Your brain has the capacity to store more information than you could memorize in 100 lifetimes (and much more) so download Anki, learn how to use it (~15min) and quickly master any type of information you want. 4a)This is NOT just perfect for language, Anki's learning algorithm is perfect for memorizing. Period.

review.review_text: I really like this app. The algorithm for displaying cards is effective. The ability to customize cards, etc. puts this app ahead of other flashcard apps, imho. However, there is one major drawback. Currently there is no swap feature. In other words, the same side of the card will always be displayed. In flashcard learning being able to star_ratingt with the opposite side is crucial. There is a method for swapping individual cards, but if you have a large set (e.g. - 1,000 Spanish words), individually swapping each card is not tenable. If this feature is added, I would rate this 5 star_ratings.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: I've used Anki on the PC for studying languages for years, and the Android app is incredible. I make cards on my PC in a txt file, import them into Anki PC, and they automatically sync. Easy, and it's far easier to be diligent about studying when you're away from a computer. Yes, the interface is slightly annoying, but the trade-off is extreme depth: sort cards by tags (want to study just verbs from your language deck? No problem), see progress/forecast charts, edit, etc. There are two different settings menus (one for Anki, one for decks) and I always flip between them trying to find my setting. Simply being able to make the cards easily on a PC is enough to make Anki is killer. No ads, either. This program is simply the best flash card program you can work. Seriously, though, its widget is the worst. I love seeing my card count for the day, but it's somewhat larger than an icon, and just looks ugly anywhere I put it. Something a bit more standard would be wonderful.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: An impressive open source implementation of Anki
review.review_text: As a former AnkiMobile user I was a bit cautious to switch to Android because I was not sure how well AnkiDroid would work. AnkiMobile is a paid app and thus support was expected. In case something went wrong with my decks I could always get it fixed by the developer. But it turns out that my fears were ungrounded with AnkiDroid. AnkiDroid has worked flawlessly in the past two months I have used it. Though I have purposefully tried not do anything complicated like adding media or even cards. I have mainly used it for reviewing and always closed the collection by exiting the app with the back button. If used simply for reviewing, filtering, searching and editing there should be no problems at all. I would say that AnkiDroid is on par with AnkiMobile. Maybe even better in some respects :D In short I am very impressed with AnkiDroid. Thank you to all the developers and contributors who spend their time improving it. Also a huge thanks to Damien Elmes. Anki is the number one reason anyone should get a smart phone.

Hands down. Anki is incredible! (All the complaints seem to be from people who have issues with (1) their devices or (2) didn't read the upgrade instructions when upgrading from Anki 1 to the new, shiny Anki 2 fyi. Neophytes won't have any issues with Anki).

review.review_text: Anki used to work much better before the upgrade to 2.0. Migration of old decks to 2.0 was easy just following directions. However, in the previous version I could easily review only marked cards, that option seems to be gone or is hidden behind too many steps but I cannot find a way. Sync is also broken, now my tablet states the time of my device is 3619 seconds different than that of the server. It's easier to shop for a new app than to spend hours wading through old, outdated irrelevant forum posts to try and fix what used to work perfectly fine.

review.star_rating: Rated 3 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: I really love the first version of Anki and I've been using it nonstop to teach myself swahili by using pictures, sound files and just direct word to word translations, and my daughter has been using it to study for her anatomy tests. I whip out my phone in long grocery store lines and study a quick 10 cards here or there. I love the functionality, the ease of use and the tracking system. I made the mistake of downloading Anki 2 because they disabled the deck sharing for the original version. I should have left well enough alone! Anki 2 is like a house in the process of being built: it's got a foundation and some exposed studs and beams, but no working bathroom, kitchen or electricity. Essentially it's a shell of its former self. Unusable. Well, says I, I'll just revert back to Anki 1 and wait until they have a full working version. So I reverted (all my painstakingly constructed decks are backed up) but it will no longer let me add cards, make revisions or sync. It no longer recognizes my log in creds. Continuing the house analogy, it's like I came back to my old home to find the locks changed. Very sad, Anki. Very sad.

It's algorithm based learning theory doesn't work well for large quantities of data. Like a language deck of 5,000 cards. Because wrong answers come back up randomly, versus assessing and reviewing all wrong answers together, and retesting them together as an option. If you need to do an assessment exam, that simulates the real quiz, Anki isn't the best.

review.star_rating: Rated 1 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: Hunh? Why such a high rating?
review.review_text: I don't get it. The droid interface is not bad, but the desktop application and AnkiWeb are extremely cumbersome. Looking for a flashcard reader I can share among platforms and users was a HUGE time waster! The AnkiWeb is awful, how do you change deck names? The desktop app is awful, I want to import and it has to be in UTF-8 from a CSV. Why? And, then I exported and the darn export file is LOCKED? What's up w/ that? Also, the cards available from the 'community' for I wanted was limited to none! I found more on anymemo or another one. But, I don't like those either, I digress. I would say that I do like the interface and the algorithm that Ankidroid uses on my droid phone. there was one other flashcard program where you could only go through the cards sequentially and you had to slide them. I'll get carpal tunnel from all the sliding, so Anki is better there. In all, I don't get the 4.5 average star_ratings, maybe 2. the time invested and lack of intuitive feel is excruciating. Steve Jobs would fire you...

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: I have really hopped around a lot when it comes to flash cards. We bought the full Mental Case for iphones and our macs. But then I decided to try mnemosyne. Then I hopped to anki, then back to mental case then back to Anki now. With the new updates to the Android app, Anki is the best flash card option for me on my android ICS tablet. Love it! Love that it estimates how long it will take me to do my reviews for the day. Love that it keeps track of how well I know a topic. This is an Excellent resource that more and more of my medical student colleagues are star_ratingting to use for exam review! Suggestion: Would be brilliant if Anki allowed attaching images to the app, if that is possible.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: Hands down best for kanji flashcards
review.review_text: I've been using Anki for over two years now and have become progressively more impressed with it as it's matured. Only problem I ever had with FCs ended up being a problem with my SD card being corrupted, and I've used it on Froyo, Gingerbread, and ICS devices. It's currently running flawlessly on my Galaxy Nexus. I love the fact that there are so many options for customizing cards/reviews, although finding all the relevant features can be overwhelming after a major upgrade since things are sometimes relocated to totally new locations in the interface. One gripe is that syncing is manual. I'd really appreciate an auto-sync feature that would update the cloud copy on completing a session or exiting the app. But what's really great is the Japanese plugin in the associated desktop application that autogenerates the furigana readings for kanji flashcards. It makes creation of japanese vocabulary cards extremely fast and simple on a WinPC. ...in fact, that's my only remaining criticism of AnkiDroid...being that I've star_ratingted using an Android tab as a laptop replacement, I'd really love seeing a similar feature available for the card creator in AnkiDroid.

review.star_rating: Rated 2 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: I had this when I had gingerbread and loved it. Never had a single problem. One of the main reasons I chose another android was for this program but the ICS version is REALLY buggy. -It crashes daily. -For whatever reason, about 75% of the time the settings button does not show up when I'm doing reviews so I can't edit cards as I go. -Unlike the GB version, this one did not prompt me to choose sync from local and I lost 100 flashcards during a sync. -Backups don't work right and I can't find a way to actually restore from backup. I had to make a whole new deck and load it from my computer, sync from computer, then sync the new deck onto my droid... -I'm getting some kind of database error now from the ankidroid PC program. -When browsing card lists, the sort option does not work (when sorting by date) Despite all this I would say it's still the best flashcard program out there. If you're not on ICS I highly recommend it. If you ARE on ICS then I still recommend it but be careful and expect to get a little frustrated but the good is worth the bad. When I get an update that fixes some of these problems I will edit my review back up to a 5.

review.star_rating: Rated 4 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: Great for learning anything you can put on cards
review.review_text: I've been using Anki & Ankidroid for over a year, mostly for the Russian Language as a companion to my night classes. It's great to make a custom deck on the computer with free Anki software, then practice/review wherever and whenever on my phone. It works best if you make your own deck. The quality of the free shared decks is spotty, and they're not super easy to browse, but there are some good ones. If you're serious about learning a subject you'd probably want to make your own decks anyway. I'm knocking it to 4 star_ratings because the sync service could handle multiple device sync collisions better, but the new version does auto backups, so I think it's better than it used to be. Just sync often if you use Anki/Ankidroid on multiple devices.
